introPages.title: Why identify the part of speech?
introPages.body:
Before you choose a word for the gap, ask: what part of speech fits here?

If you know you need a preposition, you narrow down the options (in, on, for, etc.). If you need a pronoun, you think of it, they, which, and so on.

Identifying the part of speech helps you find the right word quickly.

introPages.title: Where does each type go?
introPages.body:
Each part of speech has a typical position in the sentence:

  • Articles (a, the) – before a noun
  • Pronouns – stand for a noun, often as subject or object
  • Prepositions – after a verb, noun, or adjective (e.g. interested in)
  • Auxiliaries – with another verb (passive: are carried out)
  • Modals – before the bare infinitive

introPages.title: Article and determiner
introPages.body:
Before a noun: I saw ___ cat. → a or the

Determiners also go before nouns: its, their, both, this, that. Ask: is there a noun after the gap? Is it singular or plural?

introPages.title: Pronoun and relative word
introPages.body:
Pronouns stand for a noun: ___ is important → It. There ___ many reasons → are (with there).

Relative pronouns (which, who, that, where) start a clause that describes a noun: an organisation ___ has members → which.

introPages.title: Preposition, auxiliary, modal, conjunction
introPages.body:
• Preposition – after verb/noun/adj: interested in, depends on
  • Auxiliary – passive or question: operations are carried out
  • Modal – before verb: You should book
  • Conjunction – joins clauses: Although he was tired, he went
  • Phrasal particle – completes verb: look into, carry out

mcQuiz.question: What question should you ask before choosing a word?
options: What part of speech fits here?
mcQuiz.explanation: Identifying the part of speech narrows down your options and helps you find the right word quickly.

mcQuiz.question: In I saw ___ cat, the gap is most likely what?
mcQuiz.explanation: The gap is before a noun (cat). Articles and determiners go before nouns.

mcQuiz.question: In interested ___ music, the gap is what?
mcQuiz.explanation: Interested is an adjective that takes the dependent preposition 'in'.

mcQuiz.question: In operations ___ carried out, the gap is what?
mcQuiz.explanation: The passive structure needs the auxiliary 'be' (are, is, was) before the past participle.

mcQuiz.question: Words like which, who, where that start a describing clause are called what?
mcQuiz.explanation: Which, who, where introduce relative clauses. They are relative pronouns (or 'where' is a relative adverb).

mcQuiz.question: In look ___ the problem, the gap completes a phrasal verb. What type of word is it?
mcQuiz.explanation: The word that completes a phrasal verb (e.g. into, out) is a particle – a preposition or adverb.

mcQuiz.question: Where do prepositions usually appear in relation to a verb or noun?
mcQuiz.explanation: Prepositions usually come after the verb, noun or adjective (e.g. interested in, reason for).

shortQuestions.question: What question should you ask to find the right word?
shortQuestions.explanation: Identifying the part of speech helps you narrow down the options and find the right word.

shortQuestions.question: In I saw ___ cat, what type of word goes in the gap?
shortQuestions.explanation: The gap is before a noun. Articles (a, the) and determiners go before nouns.

shortQuestions.question: In interested ___ music, what part of speech fits?
shortQuestions.explanation: Interested is an adjective that takes the dependent preposition 'in'. Interested in + noun.

shortQuestions.question: What do we call which, who, where when they start a clause describing a noun?
shortQuestions.explanation: They introduce relative clauses. Which/who/that are relative pronouns; where is a relative adverb.

shortQuestions.question: In a passive like operations ___ carried out, what type of word fills the gap?
shortQuestions.explanation: The passive needs the auxiliary 'be' (are, is, was, etc.) before the past participle.

shortQuestions.question: What do we call the word that completes a phrasal verb like look ___?
shortQuestions.explanation: It is a particle – the preposition or adverb that completes the phrasal verb and often changes its meaning.

shortQuestions.question: What part of speech joins two clauses (e.g. ___ he was tired)?
shortQuestions.explanation: Conjunctions (although, because, when, etc.) join two clauses or ideas.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: Why is it useful to identify the part of speech before choosing a word?
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: It narrows down your options. If you need a preposition, you think of in, on, for, etc. instead of guessing randomly.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: Give an example sentence where the gap needs an article.
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: e.g. I saw ___ cat. / She has ___ idea. The gap is before a singular countable noun.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: How can you tell if a gap needs a relative pronoun?
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: There is a noun before the gap, and the words after the gap form a clause that describes that noun. e.g. an organisation ___ has 22 members.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: What is the difference between an auxiliary and a modal verb in a gap?
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: Auxiliaries (be, have, do) form passive, perfect, or questions. Modals (can, would, must) express ability, possibility, obligation. Both are followed by another verb form.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: How do you spot a gap that needs a preposition?
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: Look at the word before the gap – is it a verb, noun, or adjective that typically takes a preposition? e.g. interested + in, depends + on, reason + for.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: What is a phrasal verb particle?
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: The preposition or adverb that completes a phrasal verb. e.g. look into, carry out, give up. The particle changes the meaning of the verb.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: When might a gap need a conjunction?
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: When two clauses need to be joined. e.g. Although he was tired, he went. / I stayed home because I was ill. Look for two parts of a sentence that need linking.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: Give three different parts of speech that could fill a gap, with an example for each.
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: Article: a, the (before noun). Preposition: in, on (after verb/noun). Relative pronoun: which, who (before clause). Auxiliary: are, have (passive/tense). Conjunction: although, because (linking clauses).
